factoid: Anna Pávlovna and the others smiled to show appreciation of the vicomte’s epigram.
Monsieur Pierre broke into the conversation.
Anna Pávlovna felt sure that Monsieur Pierre would say something inappropriate.
Anna Pávlovna was unable to stop Monsieur Pierre from speaking.
Monsieur Pierre declared that the execution of the Duc d’Enghien was a political necessity.
Monsieur Pierre said that it seems to him that Napoleon showed greatness of soul by not fearing to take on himself the whole responsibility of that deed.
Anna Pávlovna muttered “Dieu! Mon Dieu!” in a terrified whisper.
The little princess asked whether Monsieur Pierre considered that assassination shows greatness of soul.
Several voices exclaimed “Oh! Oh!”.
Prince Hippolyte said “Capital!” in English and slapped his knee.
The vicomte shrugged his shoulders.
Monsieur Pierre looked solemnly at his audience over his spectacles and continued speaking.

Monsieur Pierre said that because the Bourbons fled from the Revolution leaving the people to anarchy, and Napoleon alone understood the Revolution and quelled it, for the general good he could not stop short for the sake of one man’s life.

Monsieur Pierre said that Napoleon is great because he rose superior to the Revolution, suppressed its abuses, preserved equality of citizenship, freedom of speech, and freedom of the press, and only for that reason did he obtain power.
The vicomte said that if having obtained power, without availing himself of it to commit murder he had restored it to the rightful king, he should have called Napoleon a great man.
Monsieur Pierre said that the people only gave him power so that he might rid them of the Bourbons and because they saw that he was a great man, and that the Revolution was a grand thing.
Anna Pávlovna invited Monsieur Pierre to come to another table.
The vicomte mentioned Rousseau’s Contrat Social.
The vicomte said he was not speaking of regicide but speaking about ideas.
An ironical voice said that the ideas were robbery, murder, and regicide.
The vicomte said that those were extremes, but what is important are the rights of man, emancipation from prejudices, equality of citizenship, and all these ideas Napoleon has retained in full force.
The vicomte said liberty and equality are high‑sounding words that have long been discredited.
The vicomte said that who does not love liberty and equality? Even our Saviour preached liberty and equality.
The vicomte said that people since the Revolution have become happier? On the contrary, we wanted liberty, but Buonaparte has destroyed it.
Prince Andrew looked amused as he watched the exchange between Monsieur Pierre and the vicomte.
In the first moment of Monsieur Pierre’s outburst Anna Pávlovna was horror‑struck.
Anna Pávlovna saw that Monsieur Pierre’s sacrilegious words had not exasperated the vicomte and convinced herself that it was impossible to stop him.
Anna Pávlovna rallied her forces and joined the vicomte in a vigorous attack on the orator.
Anna Pávlovna asked Monsieur Pierre how he explains the fact that a great man executed a duc, or even an ordinary man who is innocent and untried.
The vicomte said he would like to ask how Monsieur Pierre explains the 18th Brumaire; it was not an imposture, it was a swindle, and not at all like the conduct of a great man.
The little princess said that the prisoners killed in Africa were horrible.
Prince Hippolyte remarked that he is a low fellow, say what you will.
